{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2017 SX|17}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = {{mp|2017 SX|17}} | background = #FFC2E0 | image = | image_size = | caption = | discovery_ref =   | discoverer = [[Mount Lemmon Survey|Mount Lemmon Srvy.]] | discovery_site = [[Mount Lemmon Observatory|Mount Lemon Obs.]] | discovered = 29 September 2017 | mpc_name = {{mp|2017 SX|17}} | alt_names = | pronounced = | named_after = | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[List of Apollo asteroids|Apollo]]  | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 23 March 2018 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458200.5) | uncertainty = 5 | observation_arc = 8 days | aphelion = 1.4625 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 0.8673 AU | semimajor = 1.1649 AU | eccentricity = 0.2555 | period = 1.26 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (459 d) | mean_anomaly = 90.265[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.7840|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 2.8675° | asc_node = 189.81° | arg_peri = 249.11° | moid = {{convert|0.00082|AU|LD|abbr=on}} | mean_diameter = {{val|6|ul=m}} {{small|(est. at [[Geometric albedo|0.24]])}}
{{val|8|u=m}} {{small|(estimate)}}
{{val|12|u=m}} {{small|(est. at [[Geometric albedo|0.057]])}} | rotation = | albedo = | spectral_type = | abs_magnitude = 28.3 }} '''{{mp|2017 SX|17}}''' is a very small [[asteroid]], classified as a [[near-Earth object]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]], approximately {{convert|6|-|12|m|ft|abbr=off|sigfig=1||sp=us}} in diameter. It was first observed by astronomers of the [[Mount Lemmon Survey]] at [[Mount Lemmon Observatory]] on 29 September 2017, three days prior to its sub-lunar close encounter with Earth at 0.23 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]] on 2 October 2017. == Orbit and classification == {{mp|2017 SX|17}} is a member of the [[Apollo asteroid]]s, which [[List of Earth-crossing minor planets|cross the orbit of Earth]]. Apollo's are the largest group of [[near-Earth objects]] with approximately 10 thousand known objects. It orbits the Sun at a distance of 0.87–1.46 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 15 months (459 days; [[semi-major axis]] of 1.16 AU). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.26 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 3[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. The body's [[observation arc]] begins with an observation made by [[Pan-STARRS]] on 24 September 2017, five days prior to its official first observation. === Close approaches === The object last approached the Earth on 2 October 2017, at 10:20 [[Universal time|UT]], at a distance of {{convert|87065|km|mi|abbr=off}} at a speed of {{convert|26310|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}. This distance corresponds to {{convert|0.000582|AU|LD|abbr=on}}. After the 2017-flyby, it still has an exceptionally low [[minimum orbital intersection distance]] with Earth of {{convert |0.00082 |AU |km |abbr=on |lk=off |sigfig=3 |order=flip}}, or 0.032 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]] (LD). === Approaches in 2017 === {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 0.9em; width: 450px;" ! Date/Time (UT) ! Nominal Distance 
([[Astronomical unit|AU]], [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]] and km) ! Body  |- | 1 October 2017 – 22:29 | {{convert|0.001737|AU|LD km|abbr=on}} | [[Moon]] |- | 2 October 2017 – 10:20 | {{convert|0.000582|AU|LD km|abbr=on}} | [[Earth]] |} == Physical characteristics == Based on a generic magnitude-to-diameter conversion, {{mp|2017 SX|17}} measures between {{convert|6|-|12|m|ft|abbr=off|sigfig=1||sp=us}} in diameter, for an [[absolute magnitude]] of 28.3, and an assumed [[Astronomical albedo|albedo]] between 0.057 and 0.24, which represent typical values for [[C-type asteroid|carbonaceous]] and [[S-type asteroid|stony]] asteroids, respectively. As of 2018, no rotational [[lightcurve]] has been obtained from [[Photometry (astronomy)|photometric]] observations. The body's [[rotation period]], [[Poles of astronomical bodies|pole]] and shape remain unknown. == Numbering and naming == This [[minor planet]] has neither been numbered nor [[List of named minor planets|named]] by the [[Minor Planet Center]]. == References == {{reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |type = 2017-10-02 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2017 SX17) |url = https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=3781947;cad=1 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 21 March 2018}} {{cite web |title = 2017 SX17 |work = Minor Planet Center |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=2017+SX17 |accessdate = 21 March 2018}} {{cite web |title = Bus-Size Asteroid Zooms by Earth in Close (But Harmless) Encounter |author = Steve Spaleta |date = 2 October 2017 |url = https://www.space.com/38333-asteroid-2017-sx17-buzzes-earth-in-flyby.html |accessdate = 2 October 2017}} {{cite web |title = Asteroid Size Estimator |publisher = CNEOS NASA/JPL |url = https://cneos.jpl.nasa.gov/tools/ast_size_est.html |accessdate = 21 March 2018}} }} == External links == * [https://www.skymania.com/wp/bus-sized-asteroid-gives-earth-close-shave/ Bus-sized asteroid 2017 SX17 gives Earth a close shave], ''Skymania'' * [https://watchers.news/2017/09/29/asteroid-2017-sx17/ Asteroid 2017 SX17 to flyby Earth at 0.23 LD on October 2], ''The Watchers'' * [https://www.space.com/38333-asteroid-2017-sx17-buzzes-earth-in-flyby.html Bus-Size Asteroid Zooms by Earth in Close (But Harmless) Encounter], ''Space.com'' * [https://web.archive.org/web/20171003175114/http://iawn.net/2017/09/29/asteroid-2017-sx17-close-approach/ Asteroid 2017 SX17 close approach], ''International Asteroid Warning Network'' (IAWN) * [https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/iau/lists/t_apollos.html List Of Apollo Minor Planets (by designation)], ''Minor Planet Center'' * {{NeoDys|2017SX17}} * {{JPL small body}} {{use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{2017 in space}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2017 SX17}} [[Category:Apollo asteroids|#]] [[Category:Unnumbered minor planets]] {{Infobox Journal | title = Atmospheric Research | cover = Atmospheric Research cover.gif | discipline = [[Atmospheric sciences]] | language = English | abbreviation = Atmospheric Res. | publisher = [[Elsevier]] | country = Netherlands | frequency = | history = 1986–present | openaccess = No | impact = 3.778 | impact-year = 2016 | website = http://www.elsevier.com/wps/find/journaldescription.cws_home/503323/description | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | RSS = | atom = | JSTOR = | OCLC = 38524896 | LCCN = | CODEN = | ISSN = 0169-8095 | eISSN = }} '''''Atmospheric Research''''' is a [[scientific journal]] dealing with the part of the [[atmosphere]] where [[meteorological event]]s occur; intended for atmospheric scientists (such as meteorologists and [[climatologist]]s), aerosol scientists, and [[hydrologist]]s. It is a highly international journal with attention given to all processes extending from the earth surface to the [[tropopause]], but special emphasis continues to be devoted to the physics of clouds and [[precipitation (atmosphere)|precipitation]], i.e. [[atmospheric aerosol]]s; microphysical processes; cloud dynamics and [[thermodynamics]]; numerical simulation of cloud processes; clouds and radiation; meso- and macrostructure of [[cloud]]s and [[cloud system (meteorology)|cloud system]]s, and [[weather modification]].
== See also == * [[List of scientific journals]] ** [[List of scientific journals in earth and atmospheric sciences]]
== External links == * [http://www.elsevier.com/wps/find/journaldescription.cws_home/503323/description Elsevier summary]
[[Category:Meteorology journals]] [[Category:Elsevier academic journals]]
{{climate-journal-stub}}

{{About|the Philippine mythological figure|European mythological figure he is named after|Bernardo del Carpio|the Filipino basketball player|Bernardo Carpio (basketball)}} {{Infobox Philippine mythology | image = Bernardo Carpio.jpg | caption = Bernardo Carpio story as depicted in the comics. | name = Bernardo Carpio | alt = Philippine [[folk hero]] | gender = Male | region = [[Philippines]] | equivalent1_type = Asturias | equivalent1 =[[Bernardo del Carpio]] }} '''Bernardo Carpio''' is a legendary figure in [[Philippine mythology]] who is said to be the cause of earthquakes. There are numerous versions of this tale. Some versions say Bernardo Carpio is a giant, as supported by the enormous footsteps he has reputedly left behind in the mountains of [[Rodriguez, Rizal|Montalban]]. Others say he was the size of an ordinary man. Accounts of the stories have pre-colonial origins, but the name of the hero was Hispanized during the Spanish colonization. The original name of the hero has been lost in time. All versions of the story agree that Bernardo Carpio had a strength that was similar to that of many strong men-heroes in Asian epics, such as Lam-ang. ==Basic legend== The basic form of the legend is that Bernardo Carpio, a being of great strength, is trapped in between two great rocks in the Mountains of Montalban. Some versions say he is keeping the mountains from crashing into each other (similar to the Greek titan [[Atlas (mythology)|Atlas]] holding up the sky), and some versions say he is trapped and trying to break free. When Bernardo Carpio shrugs his shoulder, an earthquake occurs. ==As a revolutionary against Spanish occupation== According to one version of the tale, Bernardo Carpio was a son of ''Infante'' Jimena and Don Sancho Díaz of Cerdenia. The ''Infante'' was cloistered by her brother King Alfonso, who at that time was very powerful, because of her forbidden love with Don Sancho. Don Sancho was incarcerated, and his eyes were to be plucked out. Bernardo was left to the care of Don Rubio, who divulged the love affair. The Spanish hired a local ''[[engkantado]]'' ([[shaman]]) and conspired to trap Carpio through supernatural means. Calling for a parley, they lured him towards a cave in the mountains of Montalban. The engkantado used his ''[[agimat]]'' ([[Amulet|talisman]]), and Bernardo Carpio was caught between two [[boulders]] which the shaman had caused to grind each other. The legend says he was not killed, but was trapped between these two boulders, unable to escape because the talisman's power was as great as his own strength. When Carpio's allies arrived at the cave to rescue him, they were blocked from the cave by a series of [[cave-in|cave ins]] that killed several of them. People soon surmised that whenever an earthquake happens, it is caused by Bernardo Carpio trying to free himself from the mountain.[http://www.katig.com/alamat02.html Ang Alamat ni Bernardo Carpio (A Philippine legend) by Katig.Com] ===Etymology=== The same version says that Bernardo Carpio demonstrated unusual strength, even as a child. As a result, the [[parish priest]] who baptised him suggested that his parents name him after the Spanish legendary hero [[Bernardo del Carpio]]. This became a foreshadowing of the legendary life Carpio himself would lead. ==As symbolism of freedom from the U.S. and Japan== Damiana Eugenio was able to find and document a 1940 compilation of tales detailing the legend of Bernardo Carpio.Eugenio, 2002, pp.3-4 It specifically says that:
''"Bernardo Carpio is considered the savior of the Filipinos against national oppression and enslavement".''
According to that particular telling of the tale, when the last link on the chains binding Carpio is broken, "the enslavement and oppression of the Filipino race will be replaced with freedom and happiness." While this belief apparently referred to the Spanish Occupation of the Philippines and the later occupation by the Philippines by the U.S. and by Japan in World War II, the legend has continued to be told this way, an apparent reference to freedom from poverty rather than foreign domination. Filipino revolutionary heroes [[Jose Rizal]] and [[Andres Bonifacio]] are said to have paid homage to the Bernardo Carpio legend - the former by making a pilgrimage to Montalban, and the latter making the caves of Montalban the secret meeting place for the [[Katipunan]] movement.Ocampo,2007 ==As an etiological myth== The tale of Bernardo Carpio can be considered an [[etiology|etiological myth]] which explains the occurrence of earthquakes.Eugenio, 2002 The area which hosts the legend of Bernardo Carpio is also home to the West Valley Fault System (formerly called the Marikina Valley Fault System).[http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/GGRDDpage/projects/fault/image1/image1.htm The Valley Fault System] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070307013920/http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/GGRDDpage/projects/fault/image1/image1.htm |date=March 7, 2007 }} == In popular literature == * [[Lav Diaz]]'s 2016 film [[A Lullaby to the Sorrowful Mystery]] ({{lang-fil|Hele Sa Hiwagang Hapis}}) prominently features a tikbalang (played as a triune being played by Bernardo Barnardo, [[Cherie Gil]], and [[Angel Aquino]]) which is revealed to be the engkanto who made a deal with the Spanish rulers to bind Bernardo Carpio, effectively allowing the Spanish to rule over the leaderless people. Towards the end of the film, however, the Tikbalang reveals that it/they never chained up Bernardo Carpio because he is just a myth, noting that it is foolish to hope for salvation from a figment of the imagination. ==References== *{{cite book | last = Eugenio | first = Damiana | authorlink = Damiana L. Eugenio | title = Philippine Folk Literature: The Legends | publisher = University of the Philippines Press | date = 2002 | pages = 4–5 | isbn = 971-542-357-4 }} *{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Ang Alamat ni Bernardo Carpio: A Philippine Legendary Hero | work = | publisher = The Katig Group | date =2006-01-05 | url = http://www.katig.com/alamat02.html | doi = | accessdate = 2007-01-13 }} *{{cite web |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=The Valley Fault System |work= |publisher=Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology |date= |url=http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/GGRDDpage/projects/fault/image1/image1.htm |doi= |accessdate=2007-01-15 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070307013920/http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/GGRDDpage/projects/fault/image1/image1.htm |archivedate=2007-03-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }} *{{Cite news | last = Ocampo | first = Ambeth | author-link = Ambeth Ocampo | title = Looking Back: Natural calamities | newspaper = Philippine Daily Inquirer | pages = | date = August 17, 2007 | url = http://opinion.inquirer.net/inquireropinion/columns/view_article.php?article_id=83079 | postscript = | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070921033708/http://opinion.inquirer.net/inquireropinion/columns/view_article.php?article_id=83079 | archivedate = September 21, 2007 | df = }} ===Footnotes=== {{Reflist}} {{Philippine mythology}} [[Category:Philippine mythology]] [[Category:Tagalog gods]] [[Category:Earth gods]] [[Category:Savior gods]] [[Category:Fictional characters with superhuman strength]]

{{Infobox military person |name= Charles Fleury Bien-aimé Guilloû |birth_date = {{birth date |1813 |7|13}} |birth_place = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] |death_date = {{death date and age |1899 |1|2 |1813 |7|13}} |death_place = New York City |rank = Surgeon |branch = [[File:United States Department of the Navy Seal.svg|25px]] [[United States Navy]] |laterwork= Hospital physician |serviceyears = 1836–43, 1845–54 |battles_label = Service |battles= [[United States Exploring Expedition]]
{{USS |Columbus |1819 |6}} (diplomatic)
{{USS |Constitution}} (diplomatic) }} '''Charles Fleury Bien-aimé Guilloû''' (July 14, 1813 – January 2, 1899) was an American military physician. He served on a major exploring expedition that included both scientific discoveries and controversy, and two historic diplomatic missions. He ran a hospital in the [[Hawaiian Islands]], before returning to the US. ==Life== Charles Fleury Bien-aimé Guilloû was born in [[Philadelphia]] on July 26, 1813. His father was Victor Gabriel Guilloû (1776–1841), who had escaped from the [[French Revolution]] and fought in the [[Haitian Revolution]].{{cite book |author1=John Thomas Scharf |author2=Thompson Westcott | title =History of Philadelphia, 1609-1884 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8EsOAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA964 |year=1884 | publisher=LH Everts & company |page=964}} His father introduced him to [[Gilbert du Motier, marquis de Lafayette|Marquis de Lafayette]] when he [[Visit of the Marquis de Lafayette to the United States|visited the US]] in 1824. Guilloû attended a military academy and then graduated from the [[University of Pennsylvania]] medical school in 1836.{{cite book |author=University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine | title =Univ. of Pennsylvania medical bulletin: October, 1888 to February, 1911 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2cqfAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA279 |date= February 1899 |publisher= University of Pennsylvania Press |volume= XII | page = 279}} During 1836, he visited his father, who had moved to [[Cuba]] to start a sugar plantation after running a dance academy in Philadelphia. ===Exploration=== [[File:USS Peacock in ice, 1840.jpg|thumb|alt=sailing ship with icebergs | ''Peacock'' stuck in Antarctic ice]] On February 9, 1837, Guilloû was appointed assistant surgeon for the {{USS |Porpoise |1836 |6}} in the [[United States Navy]]. It was one of the ships sent on the [[United States Exploring Expedition]] commanded by [[Charles Wilkes]], although it was 1838 before the squadron could depart. After a dispute with [[Cadwalader Ringgold]], he was transferred to the {{USS |Peacock|1828 |6}}.{{cite book |author= [[Nathaniel Philbrick]] |title = Sea of Glory: America's Voyage of Discovery, The US Exploring Expedition, 1838–1842 | year = 2003 |isbn = 978-0-14-200483-8 | publisher = Penguin Books |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5sTHSXlv5XAC}} He befriended young midshipman [[William Reynolds (US Navy officer)|William Reynolds]], whose journals provide a non-official version of the events of the voyage.{{cite book |author1= [[William Reynolds (US Navy officer)|William Reynolds]] | author2=Nathaniel Philbrick |title=The private journal of William Reynolds: United States Exploring Expedition, 1838–1842 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5URrWfwP9jMC&pg=PT267 |date = October 18, 2004 | publisher = Penguin | isbn=978-0-14-303905-1 |page=267}} In December 1839, the squadron headed farther south, and in January 1840 provided the first sighting of the continent of [[Antarctica]] by a US Navy ship. Guilloû provided a sketch when the ''Peacock'' was stuck in the ice.{{cite book |author1 = Herman J Viola | author2 = Carolyn Margolis | title = Magnificent voyagers: the US exploring expedition, 1838–1842 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OCaAAAAAMAAJ |year=1985 | publisher= Smithsonian Institution Press |isbn= 978-0-87474-946-5 | page = 19}} They returned to Sydney for repairs, before resuming exploration.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} Wilkes' imperious manner included dismissing many of the officers, leading to further low morale. Guilloû attended to sailors injured by frequent floggings. In September 1841 the squadron arrived in [[Honolulu]] in the [[Hawaiian Islands]] to spend the winter. The three-year planned time of the voyage was over, and several members requested to leave. Wilkes insisted on reading all journals and letters. When Guilloû removed some pages from his journal, saying they were of a personal nature, Wilkes suspended Guilloû and prepared charges for various offenses. After the ''Peacock'' was lost in July 1841 while exploring the [[Pacific Northwest]], Guilloû was shuttled between various ships, officially under arrest.{{cite book |author=William Ragan Stanton |title= The great United States Exploring Expedition of 1838-1842 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l770FoaLsxsC&pg=PA219 |year=1975 |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0-520-02557-8 |pages= 144, 219, 284–286, 288 }} On his return in 1842, Guilloû helped organize the Navy's Bureau of Medicine and Surgery under [[William P. C. Barton]]. He was sentenced to dismissal at the [[court-martial]] trials in 1843 related to the Wilkes expedition, but President [[John Tyler]] reduced the sentence to a year suspension.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} Guilloû filed seven charges against Wilkes, including questioning his claim to have "discovered" Antarctica. Wilkes was found guilty of only one: illegal punishment. Wilkes was sentenced to a public reprimand.{{cite book |author1=Charles Wilkes |author2= Charles Fleury Guilloû |author3=United States Navy Court-martial |title=The following defence of Lieut. Charles Wilkes: to the charge which he has been tried |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OXIjHQAACAAJ |year=1843 }} ===Diplomacy=== After being reinstated, Guilloû served on the {{USS|Columbus|1819|6}}, under Commodore [[James Biddle (commodore)|James Biddle]]. In June 1845 the ship was sent to [[Guangzhou]] (then known as Canton), on a diplomatic mission with the first treaty between the US and China. It then visited Japan. When returning via Honolulu, at the outbreak of the [[Mexican–American War]], the ''Columbus'' was recalled to [[Monterey, California]] and the ranch of [[William A. Richardson]]. Guilloû met [[John Sutter]], and spoke French with the Swiss native on July 4, 1847; a year later the discovery of gold near Sutter's mill sparked the [[California Gold Rush]].{{cite book |author=Robert Ryal Miller |title=Captain Richardson: mariner, ranchero, and founder of San Francisco |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BTYSAQAAIAAJ |year=1995 |publisher=La Loma Press |page=134}} On August 28, 1847 he was promoted to the rank of full Navy Surgeon.{{cite book |title=Journal of the executive proceedings of the Senate of the United States |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m4SIAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA271 |date=December 30, 1847 |page=271}} The ''Columbus'' returned to [[Hampton Roads]] in March 1848. [[File:US Navy 101021-N-7642M-317 USS Constitution returns to her pier after an underway to celebrate her 213th launching day anniversary.jpg|thumb|alt=reconstructed sailing ship |{{USS|Constitution}} as restored]] Guilloû was then assigned to the {{USS|Constitution}} which took another diplomatic trip, this one to Europe.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} On July 30, 1849, while at [[Gaeta]], the multilingual Guilloû acted as interpreter for a visit to the palace of [[Ferdinand II of the Two Sicilies|King Ferdinand II]] by local diplomat John Rowan. They also met Cardinal [[Giacomo Antonelli]], who was [[Cardinal Secretary of State|secretary of state]] for the [[Papal States]]. On July 31 they visited [[Pope Pius IX]], and invited him and Ferdinand to visit the ship, with Guilloû again interpreting. On August 1, Ferdinand and Pius had their formal visit to the ''Constitution''. Pius began to feel ill, and Guilloû treated him for seasickness.{{cite journal |title=An American Navy Surgeon and His Papal Patient |author=Harold Langley |series=''The Grog Ration'' |volume=1 |issue=4 |pages=5–7 |date=November–December 2006 |publisher=US Navy Bureau of Medicine and Surgery |work=History of Navy Medicine |url=http://www.history-navy-med.org/Text_Files/2006/The%20Grog%20Ration,%202006November-December.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |accessdate=March 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726151642/http://www.history-navy-med.org/Text_Files/2006/The%20Grog%20Ration%2C%202006November-December.pdf |archivedate=July 26, 2011 |df=}} The grateful pope delivered rosaries to the Catholics on the ship; Guilloû received inscribed prayerbooks and a medallion, along with a [[plenary indulgence]]. The visit, however, proved to be a diplomatic embarrassment for the US, which was officially neutral in the [[Revolutions of 1848 in the Italian states|Italian revolutions]] that were happening at the time. A visit to a navy ship was considered equivalent to stepping on "US territory", which had never been done before by a pope. Captain [[John Gwinn]] died before he could be formally reprimanded.{{cite web |author=Commander Tyrone G Martin |title=The First Step |work=USS Constitution Museum |url=http://www.ussconstitutionmuseum.org/collections/ussc-history/first_step.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524072416/http://www.ussconstitutionmuseum.org/collections/ussc-history/first_step.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 24, 2011 |accessdate=March 12, 2011}} On his return, Guilloû was stationed at the [[Brooklyn Naval Shipyard]] from 1852 to 1854. He married Dinah Postlethwaite (1815–85), daughter of Samuel Postlethwaite (1772–1824) from [[Natchez, Mississippi]] in September 1852. They had one daughter, Margaret Acelie Guilloû (born September 13, 1853), who married George Alfred Blackmore. They also adopted Eloise ("Polly") Thibault.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} ===Hawaii=== Guilloû sailed to Honolulu in 1854. He first tried to establish a hospital with Robert W. Wood, but that failed.{{cite book |author=Francis John Halford |title=9 doctors & God |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sATPAAAAMAAJ |year=1954 |publisher=University of Hawaii}} Active in [[Freemasonry]], he helped reactivate Lodge Le Progrés de l'Océanie in Honolulu that had been chartered from the French organization.{{cite journal |author= Frank J. Karpiel |title= Multinational Fraternity: Freemasonry in Hawai'i, 1843-1905 |journal= Hawaiian Journal of History |volume= 34 |pages= 139–168 |publisher= Hawaiian Historical Society |year= 2000 |hdl = 10524/388 }} He was an early member of the Hawaiian Agricultural Society.{{cite book |publisher=Royal Hawaiian Agricultural Society |title=The Transactions of the Royal Hawaiian Agricultural Society |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lh8TAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA2-PA44 |year=1854 |pages=12, 45}} He evidently decided to stick to medicine, since in 1856, he was one of the founding members of the Hawaiian Medical Society, with other prominent doctors such as [[Gerrit P. Judd]] and [[Thomas Charles Byde Rooke]]. In 1857 [[Darius A. Ogden]], the American [[Consul (representative)|Consul]] to the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]], appointed him as the [[Honolulu]] U.S. Seamen's Hospital physician in 1857.{{cite book |author=David L. Gregg |title=The diaries of David Lawrence Gregg: an American diplomat in Hawaii, 1853-1858 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bT0cAAAAMAAJ |year=1982 |publisher=Hawaiian Historical Society |page=462}} On April 23, 1858, he gave a speech proposing to improve health care for [[native Hawaiians]] by opening a hospital.{{cite book |title=Hawaiian Kingdom 1854-1874, twenty critical years |author= [[Ralph Simpson Kuykendall]] |url= http://www.ulukau.org/elib/cgi-bin/library?c=kingdom2&l=en |volume=2 |publisher= University of Hawaii Press |year= 1953 |isbn= 978-0-87022-432-4 |page=70 }} Although the plan would later be adopted, the resulting Queen's Hospital (now [[The Queen's Medical Center]]) passed up Guilloû and appointed German [[William Hillebrand]] to head the new institution.{{cite journal |author= Richard A. Greer |title= Founding of the Queen's Hospital |journal= Hawaiian Journal of History |volume= 3 |pages= 110–145 |publisher= Hawaiian Historical Society |year= 1969 |hdl = 10524/288 |pmid= 11632066 }} Guilloû was appointed by [[Victor Emmanuel II of Italy]] as the Consul of Italy to the Kingdom of Hawaii while he was there.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} The State Department suspected overcharging for the seaman's hospital. Commander William E. Hunt in of the {{USS |Levant |1837 |6 }} was sent to investigate.{{cite news |title= Abner Pratt and Michigan's Honolulu House |publisher= U.S. National Archives |author= Peter von Buol |work= Prologue |volume=38 |number= 4 |year=2006 |url= https://www.archives.gov/publications/prologue/2006/fall/pratt.html |accessdate= March 4, 2011 }} [[James W. Borden]], the new [[United States Minister to Hawaii]], published letters in the ''Pacific Commercial Advertiser'' newspaper of [[Henry Martyn Whitney]] with accusations against Guilloû and [[Abner Pratt]], the American Consul who replaced Ogden.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} Pratt had already headed back to [[Marshall, Michigan]] where he built a majestic mansion, while the ''Levant'' was lost at sea. {{citation needed|date=December 2014}} Although Pratt was asked to return the funds, the [[American Civil War]] caused the government to never pursue the case. By 1861, the Seamen's Hospital was run by [[Seth Porter Ford]] (1817–1866).{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} Young Prince [[Albert Kamehameha|Albert Edward Kauikeaouli Kaleiopapa]] became ill in August 1862. Guilloû was one of many physicians called in to help, but they could do nothing and the young prince died, leading to a series of succession crises.{{cite news |title= Reminiscences of the court of Kamehameha IV and Queen Emma |author= [[Curtis Piʻehu Iʻaukea]] |pages=17–27 |year= 1930 |work= Papers of the Hawaiian Historical Society |hdl= 10524/961}} He returned to the US in 1867. He lived for a while in [[Petersburg, Virginia]], and then New York City. ==Death and legacy== Guilloû died on January 2, 1899 in New York of [[pneumonia]].{{cite news |title= Death List of a Day—Dr. Charles F. Guillou |date= January 3, 1899 |newspaper= [[New York Times]] |url= https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1899/01/03/102530720.pdf |accessdate= March 4, 2011 }} He wrote a book of his reminiscences (never published), and took many sketches during his travels.{{cite web |title= Charles F. Guillou papers, 1838-1947 |publisher= The College of Physicians of Philadelphia |url= http://www.collphyphil.org/Site/FIND_AID/hist/histcfg1.htm |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20101121020721/http://collphyphil.org/Site/FIND_AID/hist/histcfg1.htm |dead-url= yes |archive-date= November 21, 2010 |accessdate= March 4, 2011 }} His sketches of Oregon and California were published in 1961.{{cite book |author=Library of Congress. Copyright Office |title=Catalog of Copyright Entries. Third Series: 1961: July–December |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2iQhAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA1365 |year=1962 |publisher=Copyright Office, Library of Congress |page=1365}}{{cite book |author1=Charles Fleury Guilloû |author2=Emily Blackmore |title=Oregon and California drawings, 1841 and 1847 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RQu_OwAACAAJ |year=1961 |publisher=Book Club of California}} Grandson Charles Thomas Blackmore was born July 3, 1888, joined the British army in [[World War I]], and died on June 16, 1915 in the [[Battle of Bellewaarde]].{{cite web |title= 4th Battalion Royal Fusiliers Memorial |work= Battle of Bellewaarde, 16 June 1915 |url= http://bellewaarde1915.co.uk/memorials/royal%20fusiliers%20deaths.htm |accessdate= March 4, 2011 }} His widow donated Guilloû's papers to the [[College of Physicians of Philadelphia]] in 1974. Some of his effects such as medals are on display at the museum there. Grandson Philip Guillou Blackmore was born January 18, 1890 in Virginia and entered the [[Virginia Military Institute]] in 1908.{{cite web |title= Blackmore, Philip Guillou (1911) | work = VMI Obituary |url= http://boards.ancestry.com/topics.obits2/51458/mb.ashx |accessdate= March 4, 2011}} After graduating, he was commissioned into the coast artillery of the US Army on December 20, 1911. During World War I he also went to Hawaii, where he served at [[Fort Kamehameha]] and rose to be commander of [[Fort Ruger]]. During [[World War II]] he rose to the rank of temporary brigadier general. In August 1947 he assumed command of the [[White Sands Proving Ground]]. He married Emily Van Patten and had four children.{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} He retired in 1950 and died April 7, 1974.{{cite web |title= Brigadier General Philip Blackmore |publisher= White Sands Missile Range Museum |work= Commanders |url= http://www.wsmr-history.org/Commander2.htm |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080425032219/http://www.wsmr-history.org/Commander2.htm |dead-url= yes |archive-date= April 25, 2008 |accessdate= March 4, 2011 }} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal |title= An American surgeon and his papal patient: notes from the papers of Charles Fleury Bien-aime Guillou |author= Harold D. Langley |work= Fugitive Leaves: From the Historical Collections |pages= 5–8 |volume= 9 |number= 2 |year= 1994 |publisher= Smithsonian Institution }} * {{cite news |title= The Mount Airy Schooldays of Charles Fleury Bien-Aimé Guillou |author= Lisabeth Marie Holloway |work= Germantown Crier |year= 1977–1982 |asin= B0006Y9V78 }} Also published by Germantown Historical Society ==External links== * {{cite web |title= Charles F. B. Guillou (1813–1899) |work= AskArt web site |url= http://www.askart.com/askart/g/charles_guillou/charles_guillou.aspx |accessdate= March 8, 2011 }} * {{cite web |title= Keepers of the Culture: Kamehameha lV—(Part 3) |author= Darlene E. Kelley |date= December 13, 2000 |work= GenWeb Archives |url= http://files.usgwarchives.net/hi/keepers/koc52.txt |accessdate= March 8, 2011 }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Guillou, Charles}} [[Category:Physicians from Philadelphia]] [[Category:1813 births]] [[Category:1899 deaths]] [[Category:American military doctors]] [[Category:People of the United States Exploring Expedition]] [[Category:American people of Breton descent]] [[Category:Deaths from pneumonia]]

[[File:Kohlebrand Detail.jpg|thumb|right|View at a coal fire (China)]] [[File:Coal Mine.jpg|thumb|Open-cast mining continues near a fire at [[Jharia]] in India]]
A '''coal-seam fire''' refers to natural burning of an outcrop or underground coal seam. Most coal-seam fires exhibit smoldering combustion,<ref>{{Cite book|title=Smouldering Fires and Natural Fuels. In CM Belcher et al. (Eds) Fire Phenomena and the Earth System: An Interdisciplinary Guide to Fire Science|last=Rein|first=G|publisher=Wiley and Sons|year=2013|isbn=|location=|pages=15-34}}</ref> particularly underground coal-seam fires, because of limited atmospheric oxygen availability. Coal-seam fire instances on Earth date back several million years.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Heffern|first=EL, Coates, DA|date=|title=Geologic history of natural coal-bed fires, Powder River basin, USA|url=|journal=International Journal of Coal Geology|volume=59|pages=25-47|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zhang|first=X, Kroonenberg, SB, De Boer, CB|date=|title=Dating of coal fires in Xinjiang, north‐west China|url=|journal=Terra Nova|volume=16|pages=68-74|via=}}</ref> Due to fine thermal insulation and avoiding rain/snow extinguishment by the crust, underground coal-seam fires are the most persistent fires on Earth and can burn for thousands of years, like [[Burning Mountain]] in Australia.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ellyett|first=CD, Fleming, AW|date=|title=Thermal infrared imagery of the Burning Mountain coal fire|url=|journal=Remote Sensing of Environment|volume=3|pages=79-86|via=}}</ref> Coal-seam fires can be ignited by self-heating of low-temperature oxidation, lightning, wildfires and even arson. Coal-seam fires have been slowly shaping the lithosphere and changing atmosphere. But this pace has become fast and extensive at modern times, triggered by enormous mining activities.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Song|first=Z, Kuenzer, C|date=|title=Coal fires in China over the last decade: A comprehensive review|url=|journal=International Journal of Coal Geology|volume=133|pages=72-99|via=}}</ref>
Coal fires are a serious health and safety hazard, affecting the environment by releasing toxic fumes, reigniting grass, brush, or forest fires, and causing subsidence of surface infrastructure such as roads, pipelines, electric lines, bridge supports, buildings, and homes. Whether started by humans or by natural causes, coal seam fires continue to burn for decades or even centuries until either the fuel source is exhausted, a permanent groundwater table is encountered, the depth of the burn becomes greater than the ground's capacity to subside and vent, or humans intervene. Because they burn underground, coal seam fires are extremely difficult and costly to extinguish, and are unlikely to be suppressed by rainfall.<ref name="Whitehouse, Alfred 2004">{{Cite journal |last=Whitehouse |first=Alfred |first2=Asep A. S. |last2=Mulyana |year=2004 |title=Coal Fires in Indonesia |journal=International Journal of Coal Geology | publisher = [[Elsevier]] | location = Amsterdam |volume=2012 |issue=1–2 |pages=91–97 [p. 95] |doi=10.1016/j.coal.2003.08.010 | issn = 0166-5162 }}</ref> There are strong similarities between coal fires and [[Peat#Peat Fires|peat fires]].
Across the world, thousands of underground coal fires are burning at any given moment. The problem is most acute in industrializing, coal-rich nations such as China.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Song|first=Z, Kuenzer, C|date=|title=Coal fires in China over the last decade: A comprehensive review|url=|journal=International Journal of Coal Geology|volume=133|pages=72-99|via=}}</ref> Global coal fire emissions are estimated to cause 40 tons of mercury to enter the atmosphere annually, and to represent three percent of the world's annual [[Carbon dioxide|CO<sub>2</sub>]] emissions.<ref name="Deep underground">{{cite news |work=Time Magazine |date= July 23, 2010|url=http://www.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,2006195,00.html |author=Dan Cray |title=Deep Underground, Miles of Hidden Wildfires Rage}}</ref>
== Origins == [[File:Kohlebrand in Xinjiang.JPG|thumb|Fire at the surface, [[Xinjiang]], 2002]] Coal seam fires can be divided into near-surface fires, in which seams extend to the surface and the oxygen required for their ignition comes from the atmosphere, and fires in deep underground mines, where the oxygen comes from the ventilation.
Mine fires may begin as a result of an industrial accident, generally involving a gas explosion. Historically, some mine fires were started when [[bootleg mining]] was stopped by authorities, usually by blowing the mine up. Many recent mine fires have started from people burning trash in a [[landfill]] that was in proximity to abandoned coal mines, including the much-publicized [[Centralia, Pennsylvania]], fire, which has been burning since 1962. Of the hundreds of mine fires in the United States burning today, most are found in the state of [[Pennsylvania]].
Some fires along [[coal]] seams are natural occurrences. Some coals may [[spontaneous combustion|self-ignite]] at temperatures as low as 40 °C (104 °F) for brown coal in the right conditions of moisture and grain size.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} The fire usually begins a few decimeters inside the coal at a depth in which the permeability of the coal allows the inflow of air but in which the ventilation does not remove the heat which is generated.
Two basic factors determine whether spontaneous combustion occurs or not, the ambient temperature and the grain size:
* The higher the ambient temperature, the more quickly the oxidation reactions proceed. * The grain size and structure determine its surface area. Kinetics will be limited by availability of reactant, which in this case is carbon exposed to oxygen.
[[Wildfire]]s (lightning-caused or others) can ignite the coal closer to the surface or entrance, and the [[smouldering]] fire can spread through the seam, creating subsidence that may open further seams to oxygen and spawn future wildfires when the fire breaks to the surface. Prehistoric [[Clinker (waste)|clinker]] outcrops in the American West are the result of prehistoric coal fires that left a residue that resists erosion better than the matrix, leaving [[butte]]s and [[mesa]]. It is estimated that Australia's [[Burning Mountain]], the oldest known coal fire, has burned for 6,000 years.<ref name=Krajick>{{cite news | first=Kevin | last=Krajick | title=Fire in the Hole |url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/issues/2005/may/firehole.php | work=Smithsonian Magazine | pages=54ff | date=2005-05-01 | accessdate=2007-01-16 }}</ref>
Globally, thousands of inextinguishable mine fires are burning, especially in China where poverty, lack of government regulations and runaway development combine to create an environmental disaster. Modern [[strip mining]] exposes smoldering coal seams to the air, revitalizing the flames.
Rural Chinese in coal-bearing regions often dig coal for household use, abandoning the pits when they become unworkably deep, leaving highly combustible [[coal dust]] exposed to the air. Using [[satellite imagery]] to map China's coal fires resulted in the discovery of many previously unknown fires. The oldest coal fire in China is in [[Baijigou]] ([[:zh:白芨沟街道|白芨沟]], in [[Dawukou District]] of [[Shizuishan]] City, [[Ningxia]]) and is said to have been burning since the [[Qing Dynasty]] (before 1912).<ref name=Rennie>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/1383465/How-Chinas-scramble-for-black-gold-is-causing-a-green-disaster.html | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | title=How China's scramble for 'black gold' is causing a green disaster | first=David | last=Rennie | date=1 February 2002 | accessdate=30 April 2010}}</ref>
==Detection== [[File:Brandspalte mit Ausbluehungen.jpg|thumb|right|The effect of underground coal fire visible on the surface]]
Before attempting to extinguish a near-surface coal seam fire, its location and underground extent should be determined as precisely as possible. Besides studying the geographic, geologic and infrastructural context, information can be gained from direct measurements. These include: * Temperature measurements of the land surface, in fissures and boreholes, for example using [[pyrometers]] * Gas measurements to characterize the fire ventilation system (amount and velocity) and the gas composition, so that the combustion reactions can be described * Geophysical measurements on the ground and from airplanes and helicopters to establish the extent of conductivity or other underground parameters. For example, conductivity measurements map humidity changes near the fire; measuring the magnetism can determine changes in the magnetic characteristics of the adjacent rock caused by heat * Remote sensing from aircraft and satellites. High resolution optical mapping, thermal imaging and hyperspectral data play a role. Underground coal fires of several hundred to over a thousand degrees Celsius may raise the surface temperature by only a few degrees. This order of magnitude is similar to the temperature difference between the sunlit and shadowed slopes of a slag heap or sand dune. Infrared detecting equipment is able to track the fire's location as the fire heats the ground on all sides of it.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=J. Zhang |author2=W. Wagner |author3=A. Prakash |author4=H. Mehl |author5=S. Voigt | title = Detecting coal fires using remote sensing techniques | journal = International Journal of Remote Sensing | volume = 25 | issue = 16 | year = 2004 | pages = 3193–3220 | doi = 10.1080/01431160310001620812 |bibcode=2004IJRS...25.3193Z}}</ref> However, remote sensing techniques are unable to distinguish individual fires burning near one another and often lead to undercounting of actual fires.<ref name="ReferenceA">Hamilton, Michael S., Richard O. Miller, and Alfred E. Whitehouse. 2000a. "The Continuing Fire Threat in Southeast Asia." ''Environmental Science & Technology'' 34(February): 82A-85A).</ref> They may also have some difficulties distinguishing coal seam fires from forest fires. Combining in-situ data with remote sensing data does allow for monitoring of coal fire intensity over longer periods of time using time-series analyses.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=S. Song |author2=C. Kuenzer |author3=Z. Zhang |author4=Y. Jia |author5=Y. Sun |author6=J. Zhang | title = Detecting coal fires using remote sensing techniques | journal = International Journal of Coal Geology | volume = 141 | issue = | year = 2015 | pages = 91–102 | doi = 10.1016/j.coal.2015.03.008 }}</ref>
Underground coal mines can be equipped with permanently installed sensor systems. These relay pressure, temperature, airflow and gas composition measurements to the safety monitoring personnel, giving them early warning of any problems.
== Environmental impact == [[File:Coal seam fire.png|upright=1.2|thumb|Coal seam fire]] [[File:FEMA - 7515 - Photograph by Bryan Dahlberg taken on 06-08-2002 in Colorado.jpg|thumb|Residents evacuate West Glenwood, [[Glenwood Springs, Colorado]], 2002]] [[File:Burning mine near Denniston, New Zealand.JPG|right|thumb|A coal seam fire near [[Denniston, New Zealand]]]] Besides destruction of the affected areas, coal fires often emit toxic gases, including [[carbon monoxide]] and [[sulfur dioxide]]. China's coal fires, which consume an estimated 20 – 200 million tons of coal a year, make up as much as 1 percent of the global carbon dioxide emissions from [[fossil fuel]]s.<ref name=Krajick />
One of the most visible changes will be the effect of subsidence upon the landscape. Another local environmental effect can include the presence of plants or animals that are aided by the coal fire. The prevalence of otherwise non-native plants can depend upon the fire's duration and the size of the affected area. For example, near a coal fire in Germany, many Mediterranean insects and spiders were identified in a region with cold winters, and it is believed that elevated ground temperatures above the fires permitted their survival.<ref>nabu-aachen-land.de: Bergehalden im Aachener Revier</ref>
== Extinguishing coal fires == In order to thrive, a fire requires [[Fire triangle|fuel, oxygen, and heat]]. As underground fires are very difficult to reach directly, firefighting involves finding an appropriate methodology which addresses the interaction of fuel and oxygen for the specific fire in question. A fire can be isolated from its fuel source, for example through firebreaks or fireproof barriers. Many fires, particularly those on steep slopes, can be completely excavated. In the case of near-surface coal seam fires, the influx of oxygen in the air can be interrupted by covering the area or installing gas-tight barriers. Another possibility is to hinder the outflow of combustion gases so that the fire is quenched by its own exhaust fumes. Energy can be removed by cooling, usually by injecting large amounts of water. However, if any remaining dry coal absorbs water, the resulting heat of absorption can lead to re-ignition of a once-quenched fire as the area dries. Accordingly, more energy must be removed than the fire generates. In practice these methods are combined, and each case depends on the resources available. This is especially true for water, for example in arid regions, and for covering material, such as [[loess]] or clay, to prevent contact with the atmosphere.
Extinguishing underground coal fires, which sometimes exceed temperatures of 540 °C (1,000 °F), is both highly dangerous and very expensive.<ref name=Krajick />
Near-surface coal seam fires are routinely extinguished in China following a standard method basically consisting of the following phases:
* Smoothing the surface above the fire with heavy equipment to make it fit for traffic. * Drilling holes in the fire zone about 20 m apart down to the source of the fire, following a regular grid. * Injecting water or mud in the boreholes long term, usually 1 to 2 years. * Covering the entire area with an impermeable layer about 1 m thick, e.g., of [[loess]]. * Planting vegetation to the extent the climate allows.
Efforts are underway to refine this method, for example with additives to the quenching water or with alternative extinguishing agents.
Underground coal seam fires are customarily quenched by inertization through [[mine rescue]] personnel. Toward this end the affected area is isolated by dam constructions in the galleries. Then an inert gas, usually nitrogen, is introduced for a period of time, usually making use of available pipelines.
In 2004, the Chinese government claimed success in extinguishing a mine fire at a [[colliery]] near [[Urumqi]] in China's [[Xinjiang]] province that had been burning since 1874. However, a March 2008 ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine article quotes researcher Steven Q. Andrews as saying, "I decided to go to see how it was extinguished, and flames were visible and the entire thing was still burning.... They said it was put out, and who is to say otherwise?"<ref name=TIME>[http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1722450,00.html Is Beijing Manipulating Air Pollution Statistics?], ''TIME'', 14 March 2008 (retrieved 17 March 2008)</ref>
A jet engine unit, known as [[Gorniczy Agregat Gasniczy]] (GAG), was developed in Poland and successfully used for fighting coal fires and displacing [[firedamp]] in mines.
== Current research and new developments in extinguishing fires == ''Time'' magazine reported in July 2010 that less expensive alternatives for extinguishing coal seam fires were beginning to reach the market, including special heat-resistant grouts and a fire-smothering nitrogen foam, with other innovative solutions on the way.<ref name="Deep underground"/>
== Microbes and drug discovery == Scientists have recently begun to explore thermal vents for unique soil bacteria capable of producing new pharmaceutical leads. Soil microbes have long been a source for effective drugs<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Dias D.A. |author2=Urban S. |author3=Roessner U. | year = | title = A Historical Overview of Natural Products in Drug Discovery | url = | journal = Metabolites | volume = 2012 | issue = 2| pages = 303–336 }}</ref> and new research, such as that conducted at the [[Center for Pharmaceutical Research and Innovation]], suggests these extreme environments to be an untapped source for new discovery.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Shaaban|first1=KA|last2=Wang|first2=X|last3=Elshahawi|first3=SI|last4=Ponomareva|first4=LV|last5=Sunkara|first5=M|last6=Copley|first6=GC|last7=Hower|first7=JC|last8=Morris|first8=AJ|last9=Kharel|first9=MK|last10=Thorson|first10=JS|title=Herbimycins D-F, ansamycin analogues from Streptomyces sp. RM-7-15.|journal=Journal of Natural Products|date=27 September 2013|volume=76|issue=9|pages=1619–26|pmid=23947794|doi=10.1021/np400308w|pmc=3852429}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=X|last2=Shaaban|first2=KA|last3=Elshahawi|first3=SI|last4=Ponomareva|first4=LV|last5=Sunkara|first5=M|last6=Zhang|first6=Y|last7=Copley|first7=GC|last8=Hower|first8=JC|last9=Morris|first9=AJ|last10=Kharel|first10=MK|last11=Thorson|first11=JS|title=Frenolicins C-G, pyranonaphthoquinones from Streptomyces sp. RM-4-15.|journal=Journal of Natural Products|date=23 August 2013|volume=76|issue=8|pages=1441–7|pmid=23944931|doi=10.1021/np400231r|pmc=3862173}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Wang X. |author2=Elshahawi S.I. |author3=Shaaban K.A. |author4=Fang L. |author5=Ponomareva L.V. |author6=Zhang Y. |author7=Copley G.C. |author8=Hower J.C. |author9=Zhan C.-G. |author10=Kharel M.K. |author11=Thorson J.S. | year = 2014 | title = Ruthmycin, a new tetracyclic polyketide from ''Streptomyces'' sp. RM-4-15 | journal = Org. Lett. | volume = 16 | issue = | pages = 456–459 | doi=10.1021/ol4033418 | pmid=24341358 | pmc=3964319}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Wang X. |author2=Shaaban K.A. |author3=Elshahawi S.I. |author4=Ponomareva L.V. |author5=Sunkara M. |author6=Copley G.C. |author7=Hower J.C. |author8=Morris A.J. |author9=Kharel M.K. |author10=Thorson J.S. | year = 2014 | title = Mullinamides A and B, new cyclopeptides produced by the Ruth Mullins coal mine fire isolate ''Streptomyces'' sp. RM-27-46 | journal = J. Antibiot. | volume = 67 | issue = | pages = 571–575 | doi=10.1038/ja.2014.37 | pmid=24713874 | pmc=4146655}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Shaaban|first1=KA|last2=Singh|first2=S|last3=Elshahawi|first3=SI|last4=Wang|first4=X|last5=Ponomareva|first5=LV|last6=Sunkara|first6=M|last7=Copley|first7=GC|last8=Hower|first8=JC|last9=Morris|first9=AJ|last10=Kharel|first10=MK|last11=Thorson|first11=JS|title=Venturicidin C, a new 20-membered macrolide produced by Streptomyces sp. TS-2-2.|journal=The Journal of Antibiotics|date=March 2014|volume=67|issue=3|pages=223–30|pmid=24252813|doi=10.1038/ja.2013.113|pmc=3969387}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=X|last2=Reynolds|first2=AR|last3=Elshahawi|first3=SI|last4=Shaaban|first4=KA|last5=Ponomareva|first5=LV|last6=Saunders|first6=MA|last7=Elgumati|first7=IS|last8=Zhang|first8=Y|last9=Copley|first9=GC|last10=Hower|first10=JC|last11=Sunkara|first11=M|last12=Morris|first12=AJ|last13=Kharel|first13=MK|last14=Van Lanen|first14=SG|last15=Prendergast|first15=MA|last16=Thorson|first16=JS|title=Terfestatins B and C, New p-Terphenyl Glycosides Produced by Streptomyces sp. RM-5-8.|journal=Organic Letters|date=5 June 2015|volume=17|issue=11|pages=2796–9|pmid=25961722|doi=10.1021/acs.orglett.5b01203|pmc=4472964}}</ref>
==List of mine fires== Some of the more notable mine fires around the world are listed below.
===Australia=== * [[Burning Mountain]] - a naturally occurring, slow combusting underground coal seam * [[Morwell, Victoria]] - the Great Morwell open cut mine caught fire in March 1902 and burned for over a month. It was extinguished by breaching the nearby Morwell River with explosives to flood the mine. The fire was found to have been caused by sabotage from [[incendiary device]]s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article4915609|title=Coal mine fired by incendiary|publisher=The Advertiser|date=1902-04-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article4892274|title=A coal mine on fire|publisher=The Argus|date=1902-04-02}}</ref> * [[Hazelwood Power Station]] - a 2 km coal face in the Hazelwood open cut mine was set alight by a [[bushfire]] in October 2006<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/National/Massive-coal-mine-blaze-still-burning/2006/10/13/1160246290407.html|title=Massive coal mine blaze still burning|publisher=The Age|date=2006-10-13}}</ref> and again in February 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://report.hazelwoodinquiry.vic.gov.au/|title=Report of the Hazelwood Mine Fire Inquiry 2014}}</ref> Thousands of residents were affected by the fire at the Hazelwood coalmine in 2014 which burned for 45 days sending smoke across the community of Morwell in Victoria.<ref>{{cite news|title=Morwell coalmine fire finally extinguished after 45 days|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/25/morwell-coalmine-fire-finally-extinguished-after-45-days|accessdate=22 April 2014|newspaper=Guardian|date=25 March 2014}}</ref> Government advised the vulnerable groups of people in South Morwell to temporarily relocate due to the danger of PM2.5 particulate matter.
===Canada=== *[[Elkford, British Columbia]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tourismelkford.ca/Burning%20Coal%20Seam.html|title=Wireless High Speed Internet Provider- Tough Country Communications - Home|author=Takuya Shimoda|publisher=|accessdate=16 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100721032957/http://www.tourismelkford.ca/Burning%20Coal%20Seam.html|archivedate=21 July 2010|df=}}</ref> *[[Merritt, British Columbia]] *[[Carmacks, Yukon]] *[[Smoking Hills]], [[Northwest Territories]]
===China=== In China, the [[Coal power in China|world’s largest coal producer]] with an annual output around 2.5 billion tons, coal fires are a serious problem. It has been estimated that some 10-200 million tons of coal uselessly burn annually, and that the same amount again is made inaccessible to mining.<ref name=Rennie /> Coal fires extend over a belt across the entire [[north China]], whereby over one hundred major fire areas are listed, each of which contains many individual fire zones. They are concentrated in the provinces of [[Xinjiang]], [[Inner Mongolia]] and [[Ningxia]]. Beside losses from burned and inaccessible coal, these fires contribute to [[air pollution]] and considerably increased levels of [[greenhouse gas emissions]] and have thereby become a problem which has gained international attention.
===Germany=== In Planitz, now a part of the city of [[Zwickau]], a coal seam that had been burning since 1476 could only be quenched in 1860.<ref name="Peschke1998">{{cite book|last=Peschke|first=Norbert|title=Planitz im Wandel der Zeiten|trans-title=Planitz Through the Ages|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D2MAnDi6a34C&pg=PA18|year=1998|publisher=Sutton Verlag GmbH|isbn=978-3-89702-016-0|page=18|language=German}}</ref><ref name="wasi_DerP">{{cite web | title = Der Planitzer Erdbrand | trans-title = The coal seam fire of Planitz | work = WAS IST WAS | accessdate = 2016-10-03 | url = http://www.wasistwas.de/archiv-wissenschaft-details/der-planitzer-erdbrand.html | language = German }}</ref> In [[Dudweiler]] (Saarland) a coal seam fire ignited around 1668 and is still burning today.<ref name="mineralienatlas">{{cite web | title = Das Naturdenkmal Brennender Berg bei Dudweiler | trans-title = The natural monument Burning Mountain in Dudweiler | language = German | work = Mineralienatlas | accessdate = 2016-10-03 | url = https://www.mineralienatlas.de/?l=3741 }}</ref> This so-called ''Burning Mountain'' ("''[[Brennender Berg]]''") soon became a tourist attraction and was even visited by [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]].<ref name="fell_Goet">{{cite web | title = Goethe | last = Fell | first = Günter | accessdate = 2016-10-03 | url = http://www.fell-dudweiler.de/goethe.htm | language = German }}</ref> Also well-known is the so-called ''Stinksteinwand'' (''stinking stone wall'') in Schwalbenthal on the eastern slope of the [[Hoher Meißner]], where several seams caught fire centuries ago after lignite coal mining ceased; combustion gas continues to reach the surface today.<ref name="gem_mei">{{cite web | title = Der Berg Meißner | author = Gemeinde Meißner | accessdate = 2016-10-03 | url = http://www.gemeinde-meissner.de/verzeichnis/objekt.php?mandat=100619 | language = German | quote = An der Stinksteinwand in der Nähe des Gasthauses Schwalbenthal strömen im Übrigen seit 300 Jahren durch die Klüfte des Basaltes die Gase eines schwelenden Kohleflözes aus. }}</ref>
===India=== In India, as of 2010, 68 fires were burning beneath a {{convert|58|sqmi|km2|adj=on}} region of the [[Jharia coalfield]] in [[Dhanbad|Dhanbad, Jharkhand]]. Mine fires started in this region in 1916 and are rapidly destroying the only source of prime [[Coke (fuel)|coking coal]] in the country.<ref name="Burning Jharkhand">{{cite web |url=http://www.agencevu.com/stories/index.php?id=90&p=30 |title=Mine fires (India) |accessdate=15 June 2012}}</ref>
===Indonesia=== Coal and peat fires in Indonesia are often ignited by forest fires near outcrop deposits at the surface. It is difficult to determine when a forest fire is started by a coal seam fire, or vice versa, in the absence of eyewitnesses.<ref name="Whitehouse, Alfred 2004"/> The most common cause of forest fires and haze in Indonesia is intentional burning of forest to clear land for plantation crops of pulp wood, rubber and palm oil.
No accurate count of coal seam fires has been completed in Indonesia. Only a minuscule fraction of the country has been surveyed for coal fires.<ref name="Whitehouse, Alfred 2004"/> The best data available come from a study based on systematic, on-the-ground observation. In 1998, a total of 125 coal fires were located and mapped within a 2-kilometer strip either side of a 100-kilometer stretch of road north of Balikpapan to Samarinda in East Kalimantan, using hand-held Global Positioning System (GPS) equipment. Extrapolating this data to areas on Borneo and Sumatra underlain by known coal deposits, it was estimated that more than 250,000 coal seam fires may have been burning in Indonesia in 1998.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Land clearing practices which use fire, often starting forest fires, may be the cause of coal seam fires in Indonesia. In 1982-83 one of the largest forest fires in this century raged for several months through an estimated 5 million hectares of Borneo's tropical rainforests. [[Johann Goldammer|Goldammer]] and [[Berthold Seibert|Seibert]] however concluded that there are indications that coal seam fires already occurred between 13,200 and 15,000 [[Before Present|BP]].<ref>Goldammer, J.G.; Seibert, B. (1989): ''Natural rain forest fires in Eastern Borneo during the Pleistocene and Holocene'', ''[[Naturwissenschaften]]'', November 1989, Volume 76, Issue 11, p. 518-520</ref>
A fire season usually occurs every 3–5 years, when the climate in parts of Indonesia becomes exceptionally dry from June to November due to the El Nino Southern Oscillation off the west coast of South America. Since 1982, fire has been a recurring feature on the Islands of Borneo and Sumatra, burning large areas in 1987, 1991, 1994, 1997–98, 2001 and 2004.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
In October 2004 smoke from land clearing again covered substantial portions of Borneo and Sumatra, disrupting air travel,<ref>"Haze disrupts flights in Central Kalimantan." 2004. ''Jakarta Post'' 17 October, 1.</ref> increasing hospital admissions,<ref>"Haze thick over Kalimantan." 2004. ''Jakarta Post'' 19 October, 1.</ref> and extending to portions of Brunei, Singapore and Malaysia.<ref>"Haze thickens in Sumatra and Kalimantan, affects Malaysia." 2004. ''Jakarta Post'' 16 October, 1.</ref> Coal outcrops are so common in Indonesia it is virtually certain these fires ignited new coal seam fires.
===New Zealand=== *Burnett's Face, [[West Coast, New Zealand|West Coast]] *[[Strongman Mine]], West Coast *Wangaloa, [[Otago]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.otago.ac.nz/geology/research/environmental_geology/restoration/wangaloa/wangaloa.html |title=Coal Mine Restoration in New Zealand, Geology Department, University of Otago, New Zealand |publisher=Otago.ac.nz |date=September 1, 2004 |accessdate=December 19, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081016041053/http://www.otago.ac.nz/geology/research/environmental_geology/restoration/wangaloa/wangaloa.html |archivedate=October 16, 2008 |df= }}</ref> *[[Pike River Mine]], West Coast *Millerton area, Stockton Mine, West Coast, South Island, New Zealand
===Norway=== In 1944, [[Longyearbyen]] Mine #2 on [[Svalbard]] was set alight by sailors from the [[German battleship Tirpitz|Tirpitz]] on its final sortie outside of Norwegian coastal waters. The mine continued to burn for 20 years, while some of the areas were subsequently mined from the reconstructed Mine #2b.
===South Africa=== * [[Transvaal and Delagoa Bay Collieries]] near Emalahleni (formerly known as [[Witbank]]), [[Mpumalanga]] has been burning since the mine was abandoned in 1953.<ref name="saimm-a">{{cite web|url=http://www.csmi.co.za/l/papers/Post_mining_landuse_Collieries_jul05.pdf |title=Sustainable Development in the life of coal mining in South Africa |author=Limpitlaw |author2=Aken, Lodewijks & Viljoen |date=2005-07-13 |publisher=The South African Institute of Mining and Metallurgy |page=3 |accessdate=16 January 2010 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===United States=== Many coalfields in the US are subject to spontaneous ignition. The federal [[Office of Surface Mining]] (OSM) maintains a database (AMLIS), which in 1999 listed 150 fire zones. In mid-2010, according to OSM, more than 100 fires were burning beneath nine states, most of them in Colorado, Kentucky, Pennsylvania, Utah and West Virginia. But geologists say many fires go unreported, so that the actual number of them is nearer to 200, across 21 states.<ref name="Deep underground"/>
In Pennsylvania, 45 fire zones are known, the most famous being the [[Centralia mine fire]] in the [[Centralia, Pennsylvania|Centralia]] mine in the hard coal region of Columbia County, which has been burning since 1962.<ref name="Deep underground"/> Burning Mine, near [[Summit Hill, Pennsylvania|Summit Hill]], caught fire in 1859.<ref>"Summit Hill", in ''The Columbia-Viking Desk Encyclopedia'' (1953), New York: Viking.</ref>
In Colorado, coal fires have arisen as a consequence of fluctuations in the groundwater level, which can [[Heat of compression#Temperature|increase the temperature]] of the coal up to 300 °C, enough to cause it to [[Spontaneous combustion|spontaneously ignite]].{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
The [[Powder River Basin]] in Wyoming and Montana contains some 800 billion tons of brown coal, and the [[Lewis and Clark Expedition]] (1804 to 1806) reported fires there. Fires have been a natural occurrence in this area for about three million years and have shaped the landscape. For example, an area about 4,000 square kilometers in size is covered with coal clinker, some of it in [[Theodore Roosevelt National Park]], where there is a spectacular view of fiery red coal clinker from Scoria Point.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nd.gov/ndgs/ndnotes/ndn13_h.htm|title=North Dakota's Clinker|publisher=|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref>
*[[Laurel Run, Pennsylvania]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.undergroundminers.com/laurelrun.html|title=Laurel Run|publisher=|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref> *[[New Castle, Colorado]] *[[Glenwood Springs, Colorado]] *[[Lotts Creek, Kentucky]] *[[Ruth Mullins, Kentucky]] *[[Truman Shephard, Kentucky]] *[[New Straitsville, Ohio]] *[[San Toy, Ohio]] *[[Sego, Utah]] *[[Vanderbilt, Pennsylvania]] *[[Centralia, Pennsylvania]]
== See also == * The [[Darvaza gas crater]], a burning natural gas deposit in Turkmenistan * [[Underground coal gasification]] * [[Oil well fire]]

journal | author=Kuenzer, C. |author2=Stracher, G.| year=2011 |title=Geomorphology of Coal Seam Fires |journal=Geomorphology |volume=138 |pages=209–222 | doi=10.1016/j.geomorph.2011.09.004|bibcode=2012Geomo.138..209K}} * {{cite journal | author=Van Dijk, P. |author2=Zhang, J. |author3=Jun, W. |author4=Kuenzer, C. |author5= Wolf, W.H. | year=2011 |journal=International Journal of Coal Geology | pages=108–119| doi=10.1016/j.coal.2011.01.009 | volume=86}} * {{cite journal | author=Zhang, J. |author2=Kuenzer, C. | year=2007 |title=Thermal surface characteristics of coal fires 1: Results of in-situ measurements |journal=Journal of Applied Geophysics|volume=63 |pages=117–134| doi=10.1016/j.jappgeo.2007.08.002|bibcode=2007JAG....63..117Z}} * Results of measurements on simulated coal fires |journal=Journal of Applied Geophysics|volume=63 |pages=135–147 | doi=10.1016/j.jappgeo.2007.08.003|bibcode=2007JAG....63..135Z }} * {{cite journal | author=Kuenzer, C. |author2=Hecker, C. |author3=Zhang, J. |author4=Wessling, S. |author5= Wagner, W. | year=2008 |title=The potential of multi-diurnal MODIS thermal bands data for coal fire detection |journal=International Journal of Remote Sensing |volume=29 |pages=923–944| doi=10.1080/01431160701352147|bibcode=2008IJRS...29..923K}} * {{cite journal | author=Kuenzer, C. |author2=Zhang, J. |author3=Li, J. |author4=Voigt, S. |author5=Mehl, H. |author6= Wagner, W. | year=2007 |title=Detection of unknown coal fires: synergy of coal fire risk area delineation and improved thermal anomaly extraction |journal=International Journal of Remote Sensing |volume=28 |pages=4561–4585 | doi=10.1080/01431160701250432|bibcode=2007IJRS...28.4561K }} * {{cite journal | author=Wessling, S. |pages=75–86 |doi=10.1016/j.coal.2012.07.006}} * {{Cite book | last = Vallero | first = Daniel|author2=Letcher, Trevor| title = Unraveling Environmental Disasters| year = 2012| publisher = Elsevier [[Amazonas Region]], [[Bagua Province]], [[Utcubamba Province]] | nearest_city = | coordinates = {{coord|5.58|S|78.24|W|region:PE|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = {{Cite web |url= http://protectedplanet.net/sites/Cordillera_De_Colan_Reserved_Zone |title= Cordillera de Colán National Sanctuary |work=protectedplanet.net}} | area = {{Convert|641|km2|abbr=on}} | established = March 1, 2002 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = [http://www.sernanp.gob.pe SERNANP] |alt_name=Santuario Nacional Cordillera de Colán|website=[http://www.sernanp.gob.pe/cordillera-de-colan Santuario Nacional Cordillera de Colán] (in Spanish)}} The '''Cordillera de Colán National Sanctuary''' ({{lang-es|Santuario Nacional Cordillera de Colán}}) is a [[protected area]] in [[Peru]] located in the [[Amazonas Region]], in the [[Bagua Province|Bagua]] and [[Utcubamba Province|Utcubamba]] provinces.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sernanp.gob.pe/cordillera-de-colan|title=Cordillera de Colán - Servicio Nacional de Áreas Naturales Protegidas por el Estado|website=www.sernanp.gob.pe|language=es-ES|access-date=2018-06-16}} == See also == * [[Natural and Cultural Peruvian Heritage]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.enjoyperu.com/naturaleza/zonas-reserv/cordillera-colan/cordillera-colan.html www.enjoyperu.com / Cordillera de Colán Reserved Zone](Spanish) {{Natural and Cultural Peruvian Heritage}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cordillera de Colan National Sanctuary}} [[Category:Reserved zones of Peru]] [[Category:Geography of Amazonas Region]] {{SouthAm-protected-area-stub}} {{AmazonasPE-geo-stub}}
